intro: Fraxinus excelsior subsp. syriaca, commonly known as the Syrian ash, is a subspecies of the common ash tree native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, characterized by its smooth, gray bark and opposite, simple leaves that are ovate to elliptic in shape. The flowers are small and inconspicuous, arranged in drooping catkins, while the fruit is a winged samara that aids in wind dispersal. This subspecies is adapted to dry, rocky soils and is often found in mountainous areas, contributing to the local biodiversity and ecological stability.
